Theological Fatalism: Pike’s argument and God’s omniscience || An Ockhamist solution
5.2 An Ockhamist solution

Ockham’s answer to the problem of divine foreknowledge was to
invoke the difference between propositions which are really about the
past (those that express “hard” facts about the past) and
those which are verbally about the past but which are really in part
about the future (those that express “soft” facts about
the past). The crucial point was that, even if someone lacked the
power to do something inconsistent with a hard fact about the past,
one might have the power to do something inconsistent with a soft fact
about the past. To make such a solution work in the case of the
problem posed by Pike’s argument, it would be necessary to show,
or at any rate to make it plausible, that to act in a way which was
inconsistent with God’s belief that Jones would mow the lawn in
1/1/2000 was in fact open to Jones, because what he would be
bringing about would be inconsistent with a soft fact about the past,
not a hard fact. The difficulty for this strategy, though, is to give
an account of soft facts about the past, or at least a species of soft
facts about the past, which meets two conditions: (1) it makes it true
that what Jones would be bringing about would be inconsistent with a
soft fact of the right sort, and also (2) it is such that it is
plausible (at any rate in advance of any fatalist proofs to the
contrary) that in the case of soft facts of that sort it is in
principle possible at a later date to bring things about which are
inconsistent with them. (The Introduction to Fischer 1989, and many of
the articles in it are relevant to these issues.)

It is easy enough to give an account of soft facts which fails,
apparently, to meet the second condition. For instance we might say
that the following makes it a soft fact that God believes that
Jones will mow the lawn: given the nature of God, the fact that God
believes that Jones will mow the lawn entails and is entailed
by the fact that Jones will mow the ;awn. But that would not help
us to see how it would be possible to act in a way which is
inconsistent with a soft fact of this sort, if we did not already have
an answer to Pike’s argument. 

It is also, as we have seen in connexion with logical fatalism, easy
enough to delineate a species of soft facts about the past
which meet the second condition. We have already met an example
of one such species: “it was true in 1900 that there would be a
sea-battle on 1/1/2100.” Another example is: “it was true in 1900
that Jones would mow the lawn in 1/1/2000.” These are cases where the
truth of the propositons is constituted, in part, by a fact about
the future. But it is difficult to see how the truth that God
believes that Jones will mow the lawn is constituted, in part, by the
fact that Jones mows the lawn. Another species of soft fact that would
meet the second condition is exemplified by, “the construction of
Stonehenge predated Jones’s mowing of the lawn.” The truth of this is
constitued by a relation the first element of which does not
necessitate the second element, and the second element of which
is a future event (the relation of temporal prioriy, of course).
But it is difficult to see how the truth that God believes that Jones
will mow the lawn is constituted by a relation which something bears
to Jones’s mowing without necessitating it.

This is not to say that there could not be a solution in terns of soft
facts, but it is not at all obvious what such a solution would look
like.

Of course, the prospects of providing a solution would be satisfying
if it could be made plausible that in some cases it is in
people’s powers to do things which are inconsistent with
hard facts about the past, not just soft facts. But to take
that approach is, in effect, to abandon the idea of an Ockhamist
solution, and to move on to the next solution.
